thread.title: Summer’s over: rain forecast all next week
thread.title_full: Summer’s over: rain forecast all next week

title: Summer’s over: rain forecast all next week
text:
GRAB your brolly Sydney, the entire city is in for a bucketing this weekend and next week. 
All of coastal NSW is set for a drenching, with showers predicted for the next seven days. 
The steady soaking will start today, with late a late shower or two set to strike the city. 
There will be no relief from the rainfall, which will be fairly light but consistent. Cloudy weather on Friday morning at Bronte. Picture: John Grainger. Source: News Corp Australia 
The temperature is set to stay in the mid-20s, with today hitting a top of 28C today. 
There is a chance of a thunderstorm on the outer west this afternoon, with a storm hitting the coast later in the evening. 
Duty Forecaster Mohammed Nabi said the rain was due to a front moving through and a high in the Tasman Sea. 
“The rain will be ongoing, wet tomorrow, steady showers all day on and off, it won’t be heavy, fairly widespread,” he said. 
“Also with Sydney, there is a slight chance of thunderstorms out west, Penrith and Richmond will see some lightning.” The sunrise peeps through a cloud at Bronte beach. Picture: John Grainger. Source: News Corp Australia 
He said it will be less and less wet as next week continues. 
The mercury will drop to 24C on Saturday and continue into Sunday. The cloudy weather will continue into next week, with temperature picking up slightly later in the week, hitting 27C on Tuesday. 
The rainy weather will round out summer, which is tipped to be the warmest on record. 
Three heatwaves ripped across the country making this summer one of the biggest scorchers ever. 
The northwest NSW town of Moree had 54 consecutive days above 35 degrees. 
The hottest day in NSW so far was a staggering 47.9C Walgett, NSW on February 12.
